title: How to politely send an email to remind the recipient to reply to an ignored email - Quora

response.answer_text: Most of the answers here are simply wrong. People get follow-up emails absolutely wrong. Let’s examine some common follow-up emails and why they fail to deliver: 1. Sending a new email with a new subject line – “Did you get my message?” This follow-up is by far the worst on the list. By creating a new email thread, you essentially tell me you don’t respect me. Polluting my inbox with more of the same clutter is a sure way to show how little you care about my personal space (albeit virtual), time and inbox hygiene. The judgmental, needy subject line doesn’t help, either. “Did you get my message?” You know very well that I got your email. I simply don’t care about replying to you. You’re not going to guilt me into responding to your email by sending more junk. 2. “I know you must be super busy but did you get a chance to check my email?” “I know you must be super busy” is another way to say “I know what I’m selling here doesn’t have any value to you, and your time is much more precious than my offering but I really, really hope that you’re a nice person and reply to me.” It’s needy as hell. If you genuinely believe what you have to offer is valuable then don’t apologize for taking people’s time. You’re providing an actual return on their time. Also, people are always busy. No need to state the obvious – you’re wasting precious space. 3. “Was checking my email and noticed I didn’t get a response from you.” This one drives me bananas. I missed the news that you’re my new boss now. Keep this type of authoritarian follow-ups for subordinate, not strangers on the internet. 4. “Wondering if my email made it through…” It did. Do not wonder. And if it didn’t, your follow-up is not going to help either. ——— Some OK follow-ups: 1. Is this relevant to you? This email is slightly better than the previous follow-ups. It doesn’t pretend, guilt or judge people. It also allows the person an easy “yes/no” answer. 2. Bump. This is a follow-up trick I saw for the first time back in 2015 on the Sumo blog. It’s short, quirky and creative, so it works…sometimes.   Other times, especially with an older audience, expect to get a confused “What?” Not everybody understands where Bump comes from. It’s an activity used in message boards when you want to push an outdated thread higher on the board’s listing – you add a new comment “bump.” ——— GOOD follow-ups:  I’ve also provided the first email, so you have the context. The follow-up email: Hey David, Integrations reduce churn and increase CLTV: We offer native integrations. A lot more people use native integrations than Zapier.We reuse the work your dev team did to integrate with Zapier. Our solution is literally plug and play.I think this might be valuable to Handwrytten. Let me know if you are interested in increasing CLTV through integrations? I'd be happy to share more info. I’m not apologizing about wasting their timeI’m not being needyI’m not pretending I believe my email went missingInstead: I expand on the value from the first email “reduce churn and increase customer lifetime value”.I proceed to provide more benefit-oriented information about our offering.I address the most common objection by explaining how easy it is to integrate our solution.I confirm that I truly believe this is going to be useful for the company and use a Company tag personalization.I finish the email with a clear call to action, that is easy to answer and contains the main value. By asking if people care about the value I provided in the CTA, I pretty much make it impossible to answer No.Another good follow-up email:  It’s bad to send more than one link in your first email, but acceptable to do so in the follow-ups. Once a person receives an email in their inbox, all follow-ups will get in there, too. I've packed this follow-up with information and value for the prospect. I'm actually sharing a relevant content with our prospect that affirms the benefits of our offering without being salesy or needy. We also don’t expect that everybody will read the report, so we summarize the key takeaways in the emails. I've highlighed each point/benefit with numbers.

Here is some of the logic I follow: If someone doesn’t open your email three times in a row, stop emailing him or her.If someone doesn’t open your email two times in a row, send them a unique email the 3rd time to help increase open rates.Don’t email people too often as this will more likely cause your list to get burnt out.Leverage double opt-ins to help ensure that you are only emailing people who want your emails.If an email bounces back, remove that email address from your list.Leverage marketing automation (the video on this page is a bit salesy, but it should give you a good understanding of what you can do with marketing automation and segmentation). Don’t forget the basics Before I get into the more advanced ways to increase your deliverability, you should make sure you aren’t missing out on the basics. Here are basic things to keep in mind when leveraging email marketing: Avoid red – red is a loud color and is used a lot by spammers. It could potentially set off spam filters.Misleading subject lines – from blank subject lines to ones that don’t even match your copy, be careful using them because they are a big part of the spam algorithm email providers employ.Capital letters – avoid using all capital letters within your email or subject line.Don’t be too excessive with symbols – avoid using too many question marks, dollar signs and exclamation marks… especially in a row.Don’t link too much – from your calls to actions to links within the email, ideally you shouldn’t use more than two or three links.Unsubscribe links – each of your emails should contain an unsubscribe link. The harder you make it for people to unsubscribe, the more problems you will have.Be thorough – make sure you include a proper reply to email address and a from address so that people can get in touch with you if they have any issues.
